) is the closest international airport to Ogden. 

Ogden's Hinkley Airport is a regional airport located on the edge of Ogden.
Ogden is on Interstate 15, about 40 minutes north of
, and 1 hour and 10 minutes south of the

value: , Phone: +1-888-RIDE-UTA (743-3882) operates an extensive bus system all across the Wasatch Range, so you can easily and readily reach Ogden by public transportation from almost anywhere along the Wasatch Range.
commuter rail line runs between Ogden and
. Service currently runs every hour on weekdays (with more frequent service during rush hours) and every hour or two on Saturdays. One-way fares range from $3-$9.50 depending on how far you travel.
, Phone: +1-888-RIDE-UTA (743-3882). UTA buses travel to all of the major points around town.

Downtown Ogden is very walkable. Most of the major hotels and many tourist sites are clustered around a few city blocks centered on 25th Street between Wall and Washington Avenues.

value: First Security Building on Historic 25th Street.

is a three-block historic district. Stroll through history as you visit restaurants, art galleries, and shops. Historic 25th Street hosts outdoor events throughout the year, including a farmers' market (July through September), zombie walks, an event called Witchstock, and car shows. Inside

, on the west end of the street, there are three museums. The Utah State railroad museum is a rememberance of Ogden's railroad history, and a lot of fun for kids. The Browning-Kimball Classic Car Museum is a smaller car museum with several restored antique cars. Finally, upstairs, is the John M. Browning Arms Museum, which features hundreds of rifles and other guns from the Browning family collection. For one price, all three museums can be visited.

is a favorite of all kids visiting Ogden. It has over one hundred realistic full-sized dinosaur sculptures. There's even an animatronic tryrannasaurus rex! And while you're in the neighborhood, stop by
, one of the largest gift shops in the West.
. Lindquist Field is the home for the minor league baseball team The Ogden Raptors.

. If you follow 12th Street into Ogden Canyon, you'll see a tall waterfall on the north side of the road during most of the year. There is adjacent parking. A short walk from the waterfall, on the south side of the road, are several hot springs that flow into rustic man-made stone hot tubs.
. Go east to the foot of the mountains for awesome hiking and mountain biking trails.  Not as good as those in
, but not as crowded either. There are several trail heads along the east side of the valley.
Ogden Junction shopping, restaurants and attractions

is anchored by Dillard's, Sears, Sports Authority, and a Cinemark movie theatre.
has a variety of quaint shops and galleries.

value: content=Family owned, walk-up window type restaurant with picnic tables outside. It's sometimes dark inside and nobody is in sight, but they're still open and will come help you if you knock on the window.

There are several bars on Historic 25th Street, including the famous Kokomo Club, which was featured in Jack Kerouak's book

. There is also Roosters, a classy brewpub. 

Teazers is a night club on 36th Street that features many semi-big name concerts.

Some restaurants also feature a full bar, but since this is Utah, not nearly as many serve alcohol as might be expected elsewhere.

If you're just looking for coffee, the local favorite is Ogden-based chain
has three locations in town. The most popular is on 30th and Harrison.

value: content= One of Utah's last remaining grand hotels, and the most historic hotel in Ogden.
Snowbasin is around the corner.  It's a nice place to ski, but it doesn't get as much or as good snow as they do in Park City.  And there's no lodging on the mountain itself.

is about 45 minutes from downtown Ogden. It's accessible by 1700 S in Syracuse, which turns into a causeway. The scenic island is known for its herd of 500 bison. There is a visitor center and the Fielding Garr Ranch that you can visit. There are hiking trails and you can go horseback riding with a guide by making a reservation with

(you must call +1-888-878-8002 for a reservation; rides are $50/person/hour and it takes 2 hours to get to the top of the island). You can also camp on the island at several campgrounds. Entry fee to the park is $9/vehicle; hours vary based on the season, so check the website.
